div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: SUDAN RED SEA MAIL SERVICE
div.p: Khedivial Line's Express MAil Steamers leave Suez Docks every Wednesday, 5 p.m. arriving Port Sudan, Fridays, 6 p.m., Suakim, Sundays 3 p.m. Depart Suakim Tues. noon, depart Port Sudan, Thurs, 10 a.m., arriving Suez Docks, Saturdays 3 p.m.

Departures from Suez after arrival of Brindisi Mail. Through carriages in connection with steamer attacched to 11 a.m. train from Cairo. div.head: The Crisis And London Opinion
div.p: A London contemporary makes the follow- ing comments on the present crisis :—

"Over and over again investors have been told by their brokers during the last three months that prices have touched bottom, and can by no possibility go any lower. Yet those who have bought on this assurance have seen the fall continue, and brokers and clients alike have been left wondering whether there is any limit to the downward tendency. The bona- fide investor who trusts his security need not trouble himself greatly about this. If he is a wise man who has made up his mind not to sell, and who does not trust bis judgment to boy in these troubled times, his simple remedy is to give up reading the stock-and share lists and to put the whole subject out of bis head for the time being.

"The depressing exercise of adding up his capital values and discovering bow much he has 'lost' is quite futile and quite superfluous, What concerns the investor mainly is his in- come, and if the same income can be obtained 1r bought by less capital he need not bother himself about fluctuating capital values The case, unfortunately, is different with those who want cash and can only get it by selling securities gt present prices, as also with those who make their living by their own or other people's transgctiongs on the Stock Exchange All that can be said to them at present is that low prices offer an opportanity to those that know how to use it. For the rest, they have had the benefit of a long period of active speculation, which is followed by an inevitable reaction

"Thanks to wars and other kinds of public expenditure, securities of a high class have been created inexcess of the demand ot the public ; confidence has been shaken by the fallin values, which starting from this cayse, has affected all securities, and by the fact, which has gradually been disclosed, that a great many industrial enterprises were largely over-capitalised during the company promoting boom... .

"The British public is not hoarding its gold, but for the moment it thinks it knows better ways of making and keeping money than investing it on the Stock Exchange. It is putting it into its own business or leaving it on deposit with banks where the capital is safe and the retuarn—in the present state of the money market—excellent. No speedy change is to be expected in this respect. . .

"While depression hangs over the City aud reacts on theluxury trades, the great staple industries of the country enjoy unabated prosperity. The industries which our Tarif Reformers declared to be dying have all this time asserted their vigorous life, and the 'prac tically stationary' exports are. likely before the end of this year to reach a point at which they will be double what they were thirty years ago,

"It is scarcely to be supposed that trade in this country can be unaffected by the present state of credit, but British trade is, on the whole, we believe, a sounder trade than either German or American, and we remain more convinced than ever that the Free Trade system which has served it so well in goud times will enable it better than its neighbours to weather the difficulties of bad times.'

div.p: The International Judicial Commission will meet on Friday under the presidency of Butros Pasha Ghali at the Palace of Justice, Alexandria.

div.head: The Outrage at U.S. Agency
div.p: Enquiries are still proceeding in regard to the recent revolver outrage at the American Diplomatic Agency at Cairo, but up to now the individual has not been discovered.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: Special matinées, will be given on Sunday and Thursday afternoons by the Lilliputian troupe now performing at the Alhambra theatre, the price of tickets for which will he reduced

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: There are now twenty four cases of plagne under treatment. One death has been reported from Aga during the last 24 hours and one patient has been discharged cured from the same district.

div.head: Telegraph Communication Interrupted
div.p: On Tuesday afternoon telegraphic communication between Port Said, Cairo, Alexandria, and the provinces was interrupted owing to a break in the line, and was not restored for several hours.

div.head: Coal for Suez Canal
div.p: The S.S. "Oronsay" has discharged at Ismailia and the Bitter Lake some 4,600 tons of coal from the north of England, which is to be used by the dredgers, ete., employed in the enlargement of the Canal in that district.

div.head: Balloon Ascent
div.p: On Sunday next the Russian aeronant, Sergius Outotchkine, will make a balloon ascent at the Rond Point Velodrome, Alexandria. The capacity of the balloon is 600 metres and the inflation will begin at midday

div.head: Sport at Port Said
div.p: Next week the Port Said International Sporting Club will send cricket and hockey teams to play the teams of the E.T.C. at Snez. The Club and the Telegraph Company are rivals of yore and keen fights are sure to be witnessed.

div.head: Public Security Department
div.p: Our Port Said Correspondent writes that no credence there is placed in the report that Butros Bey Hashim's successor will be Mr. G Philippides, whose services in Port Said are too valuable and too greatly appreciated for his transference to another post to be permissible.

div.head: Level of Canals
div.p: The water level in all canals in the 1st Circle of Irrigation, will be reduced from the 20th December, and there will be complete closure in all, except in the Ismailia Canal, for at least thirty days from 25th December, on account of winter works in Galicia, Sharkia, and Markaz Mit Ghamr.

div.head: Assouan Excavations
div.p: Dr. Reisner is excavating for the Survey Department the ancient cemeteries, which will be necessarily submerged by the raising of the Assouan Dam. Dr. Junes and Shellal and Dr. Elliot Smith in Cairo are doing the anthropological work of the exploration. A large number of skeletons have been already exhumed and very interesting results are expected.

div.head: Russian Petroleum
div.p: The tender of the Anglo Egyptian Commercial Company of Alexandria for the supply of refined Russian petroleum to the Railway Administration bas been accepted at the price of LE 5, mills. 692 per English ton for petroleuin in balk or tank cars at Gabbari and 110 mills. the can, 14 kilos and 750 grammes in weight, to be delivered free in the railway stores at Gabbari.

div.head: Asphalting Rosetta-Street.
div.p: The Alexandria Municipality has been much criticised of late owing to the proposal to asphalt Rosetta Gate street at a cost of many thousands of pounds, for it is argued that very many quarters of the city are in such a deplorable state as regards their roads and that to indulge in a huge outlay on this street, which is now paved with Naples stone, is a needless waste of public money. The point of view of the Municipality is based on quite different considerations. Naples stone used to cost from P.T. 38 to P.T. 40 per square metre, but the lowest tender now put before the Municipality for these stones is on a basis of PT. 50 per square metre It is much more expensive than asphalt, as the latter has a ten year's guarantee. Consequently the idea of the Municipality is to take up all the Naples stone on the Rosetta Gate street, part of which imperatively needs immediate repairing, une ail This stone for other streets in the city, and asphalte the entire street. It is believed popularly that the proposal is entirely due to the Councillors of the Municipality and their friends who live on this street, but we are informed that Mr. Emannel Benachi, who is one of the few Councillors who actually live there, is not in favour of the projected asphalting of the roadway

div.head: The Financial Crisis
div.p: President Roosevelt's Message
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Tuesday

President Roosevelt's message to Congress, which covers more than forty columns, has been received with mixed feelings of satisfaction and discontent that it makes no mention of the Japanese troubles. In reference to the recent financial crisis he remarks that the fundamental business connections are absolu, tely sound. President Roosevelt, who is in no sense hostile to Corporations, says this is the age of combinations. The bulk of the country's business is honestly done. There must be no indiscriminate raid on companies, but it is far preferable to punish prime offenders Railway interests are not to be assailed. He recommends heavy death duties and urges immediate attention to currency by the provision of an emergency issue based on adequate securities approved by the Government under a heavy tax, thus securing its retirement as the demand fell off. The message contains no hint or suggestion of a central National Bank or commission of investigation.
(Delayed in transmission owing to faulty land-lines.)

div.head: Egyptian Estates LTD.
div.p: In an article on the present prospects of the Egyptian Estates, Ltd., the "Anglo Egyptian Mail" remarks :

With regard to the purchase of the Savoy Hotel buildings, which caused so much talk in financial circles, and which was generally OOR sidered to have been a doubtful deal, it may be recorded that offers have been received by the company this month to exchange the Savoy buildings for first-class agricultural land, calculating the value of the Savoy buildings at the rate of £60 per metre square. 1. In the course of the same article our London contemporary says:

The first transaction entered into was the purchase of three vast agricultural estates of| some 11,000 acres, which were secured At & very low price. This area was later on increased to about 15,000 acres, which the company now holds. Under Mr. R. Lang Anderson's efficient supervision these estates were gradually developed, canals and drains were opened, and new buildings provided for the tellabeen. At present a large proportion of the property yields splendid maize, rice, clover, barley, sugar-cane, and cotton crops to the hundreds of the narrative families who cultivates the land, partly as independent tenants and partly on the half share profit system with the company. Thus, these four agricultural estates have always been the backbone of the Egyptian Estates.

Anyone having the slightest idea as to the value of agricultural properties in Egypt cannot deny that the lands owned by the Egyptian Estates are worth to-day fully 60 to 100 per cent more than the purchase price, taking them on an all-round average. We can positively state that in some cases small plots of these estates are valued, and offers have been received by the company, at 300 per cent, above cost price. It is also a fact that some of this land, purchased at an average of £20 per acre, is now let on a three years' lease at £5 28. 6d. per acre per annum, which proves that the land is valued in proportion to the orop it yields- viz., at £100

As to building and suburban lands, the company's holding is very limited, and the properties were not purchased at an exorbitant price, as has been alleged. To give an instance : in spite of the financial stringency which prevails in Cairo, the Egyptian Estates have this month sold a plot of building land of about 1,300 square metres, in one of the suburbs of Cairo, 'at an average net profit of 24 per cont., and on the firm agreement that the buyer builds at once on this area a four-storey house, which will considerably raise the value of the adjoining land belonging to the company.'

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING CO.
div.p: Yesterday at the British Consular Court, Alexandria, an application was made by the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited (Araiti) for leave to appeal against the two judgments recently given against them. Leave was granted on condition that the appellants deposited the shares in court and paid in £30 to meet the costs in one case and of £10 deposit in the second case.

div.head: The Alexandria Market
div.p: The Alexandria Markét, or the French Bazaar as it is often called, is to be greatly improved. A few months ago Hassan Pasha Mohsen and Mr. William Benwell Rees bought this property from the Alexandria Market Company Limited for L.E. 61,000. The market is a very old established institution and the new landlords want to make it up-to-date in every respect. The services of a competent local engineer have been engaged in order to make the necessary plans and specifications for making the market a thoroughly first-class, modern bazaar. It is to be entirely renovated and all the latest appliances of a modern European market are to be introduced. The work is to be taken in hand shortly.

div.head: PROGRESS IN THE DELTA.
div.p: According to Reuters Cairo correspondent, during the recent tour of Sir Eldon Gorst the two points which struck him most were the great interest taken by the notables and other rich Egyptians in elementary and technical education, the large sums they were able and willing to subscribe for the promotion of educational institutions, and the extensive improvements which have been affected by the municipal authorities in the provincial towns, especially in Mansourah. These facts Sir E. Gorst regards as satisfactory signs of progress affected in the moral development of the people during recent years.

div.head: Letter to the Editor
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions expressed by out correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit – within certain necessary limits—free discursion

div.head: Britain's Fiscal Problem
div.p: Sir,- I have perused Lord Cromer's speech on Free Trade, which clearly confirms the accuracy of your special service telegram, and I can only reiterate the expression of unfeigned regret that sneb pronouncement should have been made. To accuse Europe of having been bribed into silence regarding England's position in Egypt and the Udah--for thus I read bis Landship's Word was with all submission and Not of indiscretion little likely either to find is voor with Pree Traders or to probate converter amongst the ranks of their opponents.

But this by the way. My main purpose in troubling you again in to seek enlightenment, which I have been unable to glean either from the text of the speech itself or from such comments thereon, culted from the leading London dailies, as were reproduced in the "Gazette."

Perhaps I should explain that I am neither & Free Trader nor a Protectionist, for the simple and I trust sufficient reason that I feel myself incompetent, for want of adequate preparation, to arrive at present at any definite conclusion. I fancy, however, that I have got as far as to understand the meaning of those terms in their ordinary and practical employment. A country, I apprehend is said to be Free Trade which admits, generally, all imports duty free; whilst one that imposes import duties upon substantially all articles entering its frontiers is known as Protectionist. There is however a system which it is proposed to establish in England partaking of the character of both Free-Trade and Protection, a kind of "via media" whereby import duties shall be met by retaliatory import duties and Free Trade by Free Trade. That is an arrangement which, I understand is arrived at by tho Tariff-Reformers. their policy may be right or it may be wrong. For the reasons given above I am unable to express an opinion one way or the other. But that the adoption of a fiscal policy which, upon the face of it, is in no respect unfair, should excite the enmity of foreign nations to an extent that would compel Great Britain to build many more Dreadnoughts and necessitate an enormous increase in her present military establishment, is a view which entirely passes my comprehension. On what ground could Continental states and America, sur rounded as they are by a ring-fence of Protection, reasonably object to our applying to their exports the same tariff as they apply to ones ? And why should English statesmen fear to adopt the good old German principle of "Wie du mir so ich dir ?
Truly Yours,
A. HUMBLE ENQUIRER
Alexandria, December 1st.
To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir, One of the most significant comments, which I have heard made in regard to Lord Cromer's recent speech by persons conversant with his policy in this country, was as to how his Lordship could reconcile his Free Trade principles with the policy of handicapping the Egyptian cotton mills in order to protect Lancashire. It is well known that the counterVailing duties were imposed in order to appense Lancashire, whose prosperity might be safely endangered if India and Egypt were allowed to turn out Manchester goods. I have no doubt but that this policy was forced upon Lord Cromer from home much against his will, but he had to do it and the result has been | that Egypt's development as a manufacturing country has been seriously, bot only temporarily, impaired
Truly yours
"Fair Play."
Cairo, November 30

div.head: When Cotton Fails
div.p: TO THE EDITORS OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir.- The subject on When Wheat Pails" written by Mr. Stead in the "Review of Reviews" in the October number is of vital interest to agriculturists. Mr. Stead has written further on this subject for the November number. I have on many occasions written and spoken to the Government authorities on the value of the Tafla nitrate deposits to the Egyptian agriculturist as a whole, and not only to those confined in near proximity to the beds, but without any recognition of their preserving this enormous agricultural power. Wanton waste of the valuable nitrates of Upper Egypt known as tafla has been going on for years unchecked, and it is very certain that the day is not far off when the neglect will be seriously felt. What will occur in Egypt when the cotton crop fails for want of nitrogen will be a great contrast to the present prosperity.

Since I discovered certain berls of nitrates and phosphates, (and know of others unknown to the officials) I have never had the least recognition or sign of help, but the very reverse in placing these constituents before the agriculturists, but hundreds of thousands are leaving.

the country for nitrate of soda and phosphates when a better forin of them exist in the country. I know it is only a question of time when every nitrate and phosphate bed in Upper Egypt that can be found will be worked and applied to the cotton crop, and the Government will much regret their past actions towards ignoring the deposits and those who have tried to place them on the market at a very large financial loss through opposition.

In the November article of "Review of Reviews" Mr Stead has written on the discoveries of Professor Bottomley, Botanist of King's College, London, on inoculation for the increased growth of leguminous crop. The experiments that have been carried out in various parts of the world over two years ago aremost important. The Egyptian Agricultreists will be able to avail themselves of this Inoculating material in another week, and considerably increase their herseem crops, and consequently their cotton at a cost of shout 10 piastres and acre
Truly yours,
A.J. Monson
London, November 18th

div.head: Deirout Post office
div.p: A correspondent writing from Deirout complains of the inefficiency of the Post Office there, due to it being understaffed. He demands that,
(1) An assistant clerk be appointed
(2) Private correspondence be delivered at houses
(3)Merchants be allowed to sell postage stamps
(4)Borton Bey pay a visit of inspection to the Post Office to See that these Demands are not excessive

div.head: Christmas Letters
div.p: The following are the days on which correspondence to arrive in England for Christmas should be posted.

div.head: The Seamen's Home
div.p: A most enjoyable concert was given on Monday night at the Seamen's Home at Alex andria, the host of the evening and organiser of the concert being Mr. Hilary Moss. With the Rev. H. Reid in the chair, the Rev. B. H. Blyth as accompanist, Mr. Mobb as director general, and a goodly company or willing and able contributors to an impromptu programme the discovery. things went merrily and performers andаudience alike were pleased with their evening's entertainment. Mr. Moas set the ball rolling with "The Young British Soldier" and Mr. Donglas Allen followed with "The Balloymoney Conversazione" which he sang with such humour that, like Oliver Twist, we all asked for more. We got it too; a characteristic rendering of "I burst out laughing", and we joined him in the laugh. Mr. Clarke was warmly applauded for be rendering of "My Ola Dutch," and Mr. Hobsbaum's "Gallery and Boxes" was most humorous and enjoyable. Mr. Pearoe Fill gave the audience a great treat, assisted at the piano by Mr. R. Sanguinetti, who also gave a good selection from the "Geisha", which was excellently played. Converting his massive fist into the physiognomy of a dear little girl of six years, Mr. Pearbe Hill amused us with a ten minutes' ventriloquial conversation and songs, recitations, and the like and later in the evening he persuaded Mr. and Mrs Sawdust to ring a duet, though the former was distinctly rude at times. We cannot, however, describe the programme in detail, our space being curtailed by pressure of news. Pleasure was derived from each and every item, and we were very glad to see the number of sailors who volunteered contributions. The Moss orchestra quintette from the "Seti" were excellent and several other good items were given by men from Moss liners, and as a wind-up we had a humorous sketch entitled "The Amateur Doctor". The evening was concluded with a vote of thanks to Mr. MOBA and the performers and three cheers for Mr. Blyth, who was indefatigable at the piano. In the interval between the first and second parts of the programme tea and bans were served to the men.

div.head: Gum Arabic Movements
div.p: In the London commercial market Sudan gum last week, was steady, with a small business doing at tull rates, fair balf hard sorts at 378 6d to 38s, and good ordinary at 368 6d; for arrival 365 to 378 is quoted, without business resulting. In auction 131 bales Soudan sorts, 10 bales Aden and 27 packages Australian were all retired. Persian sorts were dull and sales unimportant; ordinary are being offered at 108 6d. Mohomerah search and higher prices asked.

div.p: The following programme of music will be played at the Helouan Casino on Sunday next, commencing at 3.88 p.m. by the band of the King's Royal Rifles :
T. Brown, Bandmaster

The Temps" states that three telephone Lines have recently been opened on the borders of Upper Senegal and the Central Niger region The sections are from Kaya to Medine, from Kati to Bammako, and, lastly, one for the district of Kulikovo. These two last mentioned lines are mutually connected. The price of a five minutes' conversation ranges from 5d. to 7fd., and the annual subscription amounts to £6. There is every reason to believe that in the course of a few months Time buktu will also have its telephone.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: The Earl and Countess of Rothes are leaving or Egypt early this month.

The Earl of Crawford and Balcard . S.T. "Valbella" has proceeded from Port Said to Suez, there to await the party which accompanied the Earl to Egypt and to take theta through the Odnal and along the set out.

Sir G. T. Goldie was last week blected an Alderman of the London County Coppoil to ml the vacancy caused by the resignation of Bir Vincent Caillard, of the London Ryeney of the National Bank of Egypt.
Sir Powell Bakton has returned to 2, Princes Gate, London, from Egypt.
Countess Arnim arrived at Helouan last week and is now staying at the "Al Hayat" where she will remain for the whole season.
Dr. von Campe, the well known physician from Hanover, has arrived at the "Al Hayat," Helouan, for the season.
Mrs. Harvey (Irene Osgood) sailed last Thursday on board the "Heliopolis" from Greenock for Alexandria She will spend the winter in Cairo, and will write a book there.
Count Bernstorff, German Diplomatie Agent, is to-might entertaining to dinner the Duke of Brunswick, Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst, Mr. and Lady Valda Machell, and others.

div.head: The Levy Afffair
div.p: A contemporary states that Samvel Levy, ex-cashier of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo, has had bis sentence reduced to a month and a half imprisonment by the President of the French Republic.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE
div.p: The Russian S.S. "Tsat arrived at Port Said yesterday morning with 275 pilgrims, the German 8.8. "Sicilia" with 588 and the Turkish 88. "Ismir" with 679, all three ships entered the capital yesterday bound for Djeddah.

div.p: The Moss liner "Menepthal" strived yesterday morning from Liverpool vid Qibraltar, Algiers and Malte, with passenger, mails una general cargo

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi)

Il est difficile de définir le caractère du marché. Les affaires font à peu près complètement défaut par manque de vendeurs, dit-on, et cependant on éprouve de l'ensemble un sentiment de lourdeur et de lassitude ; il serait peut-être plus exact de dire que les acheteurs ne montrent encore que peu d'empressement et que de leur côté les vendeurs de naguère rassurés en partie par la reprise de ces derniers jours et par la baisse du taux d'escompte, ne se hâtent plus de liquider, dans l'attente de plus hauts prix.

Quoi qu'il en soit, les valeurs dirigeantes ont été généralement négligées à une fraction minime de baisse. Ainsi l'Agricole revient de 7 29/32 8 7 7/8, la National Bank de 20 1/2 à 20 7/16 et la Deltalight de 9 25/32 à 9 3/4. Seule de cette catégorie, la Daïra demandée avance de 12 13/16 à 13
On a également constaté une demande assez active en Nile Land qui gagne de ce chef 1/4 à 8. Il parait même qu'elle aurait été traitée au Caire à un prix supérieur.
Pour le même motif les Lots Turcs progressent de 159 à 160, la Banque d'Athènes de 113 1/4 à 113 3/4, l'Urbaine de 3 3/8 à 3 7/16 et le Banco di Roma de 102 à 103.
Au contraire, le Crédit Franco Égyptien rétrograde de 4 7/32 à 4 3'16 et la Land Bank de 7 9/32 à 7 1/4.

En petites valeurs, les Markets perdent 6 pence à 24/-, les Dividendes Bière du Caire 6 franes à 20, l'Ordinaire Khedivial Mail 9 pence à 22/-, les Estates 1/8 à 13/32, ainsi que le Comptoir à 2 17/32; tandis que la Cassa di Sconto gagne 2 francs à 45, la Delta Land 1/32 1 9/32, l'Aboukir 1 shelling à 28/6, le fondateur Allotment 1 P.T. à 46 et la Port Said Salt 1 pence 1/2 à 12/6.

Sur le reste de la côte il n'y a pas de changements à signaler. On aura observé que les fluctuations enregistrées sont assez inégales. Elles rendent parfaitement l'allure du marché sui. vant la demande ou l'offre dont les valeurs ont été l'objet

Comme tendance il n'est pas possible d'en donner une, sinon que la plupart, haussiers et baissiers se tiennent dans l'attente des événements. Il faut dire aussi que les capitaux manquent pour entraîner le marohe.

A la Chambre commerciale du Caire, Me Chalom demandait au tribunal l'homologation du concordat préventif voté par les créanciers de la maison Palacci fils, Haïm et Cie. Pour un certain nombre de créanciers représentant la minorité, Mes Manusardi et Morpurgo s'opposaient de toute leur énergie à cette homologation, s'appuyant surtout sur le fait que M.M. Palacci fils et Cie avaient spéculé sur les va leurs de Bourse et sur ventes et achats de terrains. "C'est là la cause de leur situation embarrassée; ils ne sont pas des débiteurs malheureux, Le concordat préventif ne doit donc pas leur être accordé".
A huitaine la décision du tribunal.

div.head: Egyptian Constructions Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT AN EXTRAORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the above named Company will be held at the Grand Continental Hotel Cairo on Saturday the 21st day of December 1907 at four o'clock in the afternoon, at which the following Resolutions will be submitted,
a) by cancelling 12,500 Shares numbered 5,001 to 7,500 and 100,001 to 110,000 each fully paid.
b) by reducing each of the 109,500 Shares numbered 1 to 5,000 750 to 100,000-110,001 to 122,000 each fully paid, from £1 to ten shillings.

2. That each of the 78,000 Shares of £1 each remaining unissued shall be divided into two shares of ten shillings each. Should the above resolutions be duly passed by the requisite majority of the same will be duly submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions to a subsequent General Meeting of the Company which will be held at the same time and place on Wednesday the 8th day of January 1908. At the same Meeting a Resolution will be submitted by the Directors authorizing them to sell or otherwise dispose of certain portions of the businesses acquired by the Company Holders of bearer warrants must deposit them at the ANGLO EGYPTIAN BANK either at Cairo or Alexandria at least 48 hours before the Meeting.

Shareholders who have not taken up their bearer warrants may do so without further formality. Proxies must be left at the Com. panys Offices at 18 Chareh Abdeen, Cairo, at least 48 hours before the Meeting and should be in proper form.
By order of the Board
Jackson H. BROOKS. 31461-3-1
Secretary in Egypt.

div.head: Administration of Ports & Lights
div.p: Notice to Marineers
Mediterranean, Egypt, Alexandria Harbourg
With reference to Notice to Mariners of September 28th 1907, regarding the new beacon to be placed at the outer entrance to the Great Pass, notice is hereby given that the beacon is now in position.
A fixed white light will be placed on it temporarily, and the gas buoy removed.
When the Great Pass is opened to traffic, this fixed light will be changed to a white occulting light with a period of 5 seconds (approximately). The light will be unwatched.
When the Great Pass is opened to traffic, this fixed light will be changed to a white occulting light with a period of 5 seconds (approximately). The light will be unwatched.

Bearings are magnetic and taken from the beacon Name-Great Pass Gas Beacon. Colour-Chocolate. Depth of water alongside-24 to 26 feet. Height of focal plane above H.W.47 feet. General description-Open iron work. Miles seen in clear weather - 5.
New Leading Light for Great Pass
A front leading light has been erected for the Great Pass on the Mex shore and lights will be exhibited from it when the Pass is opened to traffic.
There will be three fixed lights placed vertically shown from the tower, the upper and lower being red, and the centre one white.
POSITION OF TOWER
Bearings are magnetic and given from the lighthouse

Name - Great Pass Low Light. General Description-- Masonry, circular, with red and white bands, and the lantern sur. mounted by spike and ball, dwellings with red roots, adjacent. Height of tower - 64 feet. Top of tower to H.W. - 72 feet. Height of Upper light above H.W. - 58 feet. Centre light above H.W. - 43 feet Lower light above H.W. - 28, Miles seen in clear weather - 5 Character of Apparatus, or Order C.D. 4th Order.
The Great Pass

The dredging of the Great Pass bas been completed, and it is expected that it will be opened to traffic about the end of the present year after the survey is completed. The pass is 600 feet wide, and will have a least depth of 35 feet throughout its length.
Leading Marks etc.

At the outer entrance on the Southern side is placed the Gas beacon, before mentioned. Just off the Southern side, on a rock with about 8 feet of water on it, which lies to the Northward of the Hydrographer shoal, and within about 30 yards from the sideline of the Pass, will be placed an open iron work beacon.

Off the Northern side, on the South end of the North shoal, will be placed a similar beacon. Full description of these beacons will be given when they are in position. On the shore, is the lighthouse before mentioned, and there will also be iron beacons to mark the sides of the Pass, in the same manner as the Boghaz Pass. Full description of these beacons will be given when they are erected. To enter the Pass from seaward, keep the Great Pass Low Lighthouse in line with the Mex High Lighthouse, by day, and the five lights in line vertically, by night, on a bearing 8. 67° E (true) which will lead through in noi less than 35 feet of water.

When the Great Pass is opened the Boghaz Pass will be closed for night traffic, and the two red lights in Mex Low Lighthouse will pot be exhibited, until further notice, to date from the commencement of the sense of the Great Pass. The exact true bearing of the centre line of the Great Pass, through the centres of Mex High Lighthouse, and Great Pass Low Light house is :
DREDGING LIGHTS
The use of these lights has been discontinued, and the poles on which they were placed will shortly be removed.
Mex High & Low Lights
The lights in the Mex High and Low Lighthouses have been changed from C.D. 6th Order to C.D. 4th Order.
HERBERT J. GEDGE
For Director General 31460-2-1
Alexandria, November 18th 1907.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress confirms the forecast. He asks for authority to remit the balance of the Chinese indemnity, and urges American help for the educator of the Chinese in every practicable way, especially to promote the coming of Chinese students to America. He refers to the Japanese Exhibition of 1912 as an occasion of special interest to all nations. He urges immediate generous provision for American representation in view of the intimate Jap-American trade relations and the warm friendship uninterruptedly maintained since Japan's opening into Western intercourse and in view of her increasing wealth and production which are regarded by America with hearty good-will. He recommends the establishment of more docks and coaling stations in the Pacific.
Viscount Aoki has been recalled to personally report to the Mikado the situation in America relative to the immigration problem.(Reuter)

Deputy Luzatti, who has been several times Minister of the Treasury and is considered one of the greatest European financiers, discussing the financial crisis in the United States pointed out the defects of the American banking system and suggested & remedy. Professor Luzzatti - advocates the convocation of an international conference aiming at the substitution of the struggle for gold by the co-operation for an equanimitous distribution of gold through agreements between the State banks and the treasures of the different States.

This conference should examine and compare the regulations of the State banks with the object of making them more adapted to prevent financial crisis or mitigate them. Besides, considering that some European State banks already exchange gold loans, the Conference should study the best way of regular: ing these loans permanently and to the general advantage. (Reuter)
An engine daybed into a gang of platelayers near Paisley. Seven of them have been killed. (Reuter)
Vere Goold has been sentenced to imprisonment with hard labour for life and his wife to death. (Rerster)

he Pope received in audience the members of the Anti-Slavery Congress. He said that he had followed their reports with the greatest interest, especially those re'ating to Egypt describing the anti slavery struggles of the missionaries and British authorities, (Router)
The Government is considering the formation of two army corps, to consist largely of Arabs of Algeria (Reuter)

A woman to-day threw a bomb at the carriage in which General Guercheimann, the Governor-General, was driving. He escaped unhurt but the coachman was wounded and his horses were killed. The woman is dying. (Reuter)
The wholesale exodus of aliens from America is causing alarm in Germany and Italy as they are adding to the hungry hordes and overcrowded labour market. (Reuter)
The report of the Secretary of the Treasury is featureless. He says that something should be done to make currency more elastic but the form of legislation must be left to Congress. (Reuter)

Martial law has been proclaimed in Zululand. The situation is more serious owing to the attitude of the Natal natives. The total fighting strength of the Zolus is 80,000 men many of whom are armed with rifles. Preparations are being made to cope with a general rising (Reuter)
The King and Queen of Spain have left for home. (Reuter)

Mr. Taft has been entertained at a banquet by the Americans bere. He said there was not the slightest possibility or reason for a war between the United States and any other country. The foundation stone of American policy was peace with all nations. (Reuter)
The Cotton Conference yesterday was readjusted. The crisis is still acute. (Reuter)
REMARKS.
There is no change in the weather conditions. This morning opens nice and clear with a light E. breeze and a falling barometer.

div.head: Monet and Share Market
div.p: From our Financial Corresponent
London, November 29
The Money Market

At the time of writing it would certainly seem that the cloud which has been banging over the money market during the past few weeks is lifting, and that shortly we may see a return to something approaching more normal conditions. The reports from America are now more optimistic, and it is to-day announced that the subscription lists for the Treasury certificates of indebtedness have been closed. This may of course, be interpreted to mean that the objections which American bankers have levelled against this new form of currency have induced Mr. Cortelyou to decide not to issue the whole of the 100 million dollars originally authorised, but the market bere seems to have taken the other view that the improvement in the situation is responsible for the closing of the list. In any case, the shipments of gold from London show an appreciable falling off, and that, after all, is the most satisfactory development from our point of view. As the shipments of Egyptian cotton are now proceeding apace, it may be expected that your country will call for the balance of the gold required in the near future, and a cessation of the American demand will enable the Bank of England to supply Egypt's needs without very much inconvenience. It is, of course, still too early to give any reliable forecast of probable developments in the States, as a very great deal must depend upon the public. If they persist in boarding their money, the situation may again become critical when the banks and other institutions recommence payments in cash. Our own bank position is much improved, and events have all contributed towards a lowering of rates. In the first place, the whole of the £4,860,000 transferred from Russian balances to Japanese credit, an account of expenses in connection with Russian prisoners of war, immediately became available after transfer, and was secured by the market for two months. Then, too, the Bank of Pranoe have now somewhat modified their refusal to ship gold direct to New York, and have released a quantity of American engles on the security of commercial bills endorsed or the leading French bankers, Another favourable point has been the release by the Indian Government of one million of the five-and-a quarter millions held to their credit at the Bank of England, and it is also satisfactory to know that a further substantial quantity of Indian gold will be released if necessary The Bank return this week shows an addition of alose upon two millions to the reserve. The sum of one and a half million was received on balance from abroad, and about a quarter of a million in coin returned from the country. The increase in the reserve is therefore £1,870,000, bringing up the total to £21,785,603, as compared with £23,613,809 in the corresponding week of 1906. The proportion to liabilities is 4.05 higher on the week at 38.78 per cent. Last year the proportion was 44.92 per cent. Demands for accommodation in connection with the Stock Exchange settlement yesterday gave the money market a somewhat harder appearance, and short loans realised 5 to 6 per cent. The Bank lent a small sum for a week at 175 per cent. Three months' fine bills hardened from 37 to 6g. We are glad to note that Sir Felix Schuster, in his inaugural address as President of the Institute of Bankers, on Wednesday, gave the assurance that the committee of clearing house bankers appointed to consider the question of gold reserves were determined to bring their labours to & successful conclusion, and that be was confident that a suitable soheme, which would have the general co-operation of the banking community, would be devised especially now that the necessity that had been once more clearly demonstrated. He believed the general position in this respect all over the country was already far stronger than ever before. When the situation became more normal, he bad every hope that discussion would lead to action, and that bankers themselves would take steps which would render legislation or even talk ot legislation quite unnecessary. Legislation on this question was to be avoided if it possibly could be We await the publication of the committee's report with much interest.
Silver.
The quotation for silver, after dropping on Wednesday to 264 for immediate delivery, yesterday recovered, and left off with an advance of A to 26, H. The forward price was 27
The Stock Markets,

The improvement in the American position, and the belief that the withdrawals of gold from the Bank of England will now soon cease, added to the substantial improvement in the money situation which has already taken place, has been reflected on the Stock Exchange, and the tone this week was been much more cheerful. Business still continues to be restricted, but this is of course natural, considering the fact that there must be for some time to come a certain amount of uncertainty regarding the course of events in the States. A crisis such as the one through which that country has been passing cannot be got rid of in a day, and its effects upon the share markets of the world will continue for some time to come, even assuming that there is no no further set-vack. It is something however to see a tone of optimism take the place of the gloom which has recently prevailed. Active business can certain y not be expected until the turn of the year. The feature of the week has been the strength of home railway shares. These have been much in favour since the settlement of the dispute, and not a few wise investors have taken advantage of the low prices to lock up & quantity of the better-class stocks. The home railway market has received a further filly from the announcement of a contemplated working arrangement between the Great Northern and Great Central companies, where: by, it is hoped, much of the ruinous competition now prevailing may be curtailed, There is a very unnecessary duplication of trains running to the northern towns, and the proposed agreement should affect a considerable saving, and consequent addition to the profits.
The monthly settlement has passed quietly, and no failures have been reported.
Consols

The gilt-edged market has been much firmer, and Consoles at one time yesterday were up to 82 ½ but closed at 82 ¾ , at which figure they showed a rise off on the week. To-day they leave off at 82 3/16
Foreign Bond

The Foreign market has been very steady on Continental support. The continued buying of Russian Bonds has been a prominent feature, Paris having taken large blocks of these during the last few days. The Fours yesterday left off with an advance of 1 ¼ at 79 ½ , and Fives were higher at 88 ¼ . Last Friday we quoted these Bonds at 76 ¼ and 86 ¼ respectively. Japanese Stocks have also been well supported and are generally higher. Russian Fours have to-day advanced ¾ and the Fives ¼
Home Rails

A working agreement between the Great Northern and the Great Central railway companies, which has been in process of negotia. tion for a long time past, is now within sight of being realised. An arrangement has been drawn up, and will be submitted to the shareholders of the respective companies in due course. Expenses on the railways have increased at such an alarming rate in recent years owing to the competition of the various lines running to the north, that some means of cutting down these by mutual cooperation between the companies has become absolutely necessary.
Americans

The tone of Americans has been less on settled since our last, and it is now confidently hoped that the worst is over. It is of course, a matter of doubt as to how long it will take to restore public confidence, and meanwhile dealings will probably continue on a small scale.

This week movements have been interrupted by the Thanksgiving Day holiday in New York yesterday, but on the whole prices are higher on balance. To-day Americans have been restricted sending receipt of New York quotations. The chief movement is an anadvance of 1 ½ in Canadian pacifies 149 ¾ .
Egyptians

There has been decidedly more doing in the Egyptian market during the past week, and prices in most cases are very much better. The National Bank of Egypt have been a good market, rising to 20 ½ , and Agricultural Bank, after being very flat at 7, to have advanced rapidly to 7 15/16 bid. The preference keep firm at 9 but the 3 ½ Debentures are still a bad market at 80-2. Daira Sanieh have also been in request, closing 12 ½ , which is an advance of about on balance. The Deferred are unmentioned at 65-70. Delta Land and Investment after being 1 ½ , were strong yesterday, and closed 1 1/4 -, with buyers about at 1, A. There are also buyers of Delta Preference Bearer at 9 ¾ -10, but at present there is not much doing in these shares. Khedivial Mail are no better on the dividend, and remain at 21/-8. Corporation of Western Egypt have been dealt in at 8s. 9d. and 9/-s., and Egyptian Estates are unchanged at ⅜
Mining

In the early part of the week mining shares were firm, being helped by the disclosure that the speculative position open, was very small. During the past two days, however, movements have been dull and irregular, owing to weakness in Paris, and several of the leading counters gave way. Yesterday towards the close some of these were bid for, and recovered their earlier loss. De Beers Deferred closed ½ better
The closing prices are as follows:

div.head: Avis
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux d'Asphaltage d'un partie de la Rue Porte Rosette.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L. Eg. 1,300.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 24 Décembre 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour "Asphaltage Rue Porte Rosette.

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 24 décembre à mai.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 30 Novembre 1907.
(Sigué) W.P. CHATAWAY,

div.head: Avis
div.p: EMPRUNT MUNICIPAL--AMORTISSEMENT

Conformément aux avis insérés dans les journaux locaux et aux conditions spéciales réglant le tirage des titres, il a été procédé, le 2 Décembre 1907, à 5h. 1/2 p.m., au Palais Municipal, en séance publique, au ler tirage de 21 titres de l'Emprunt Municipal, du ler janvier 1902, et ce, en vue de leur amortissement.
Sont sortis au tirage, les numéros suivants : 1o. No 269 des titres de L.E. 50).
Ces titres seront remboursés, au pair, le ler Janvier 1908, par la National Bank of Egypt, à Alexandrie, au Caire et à Londres. Alexandrie, le 3 Décembre 1907.
L'Administrateur, 31449-3-2
W. P. CHATAWAY

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien.
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au Mercredi, huit Janvier 1908, à midi au plus tard, des offres pour l'achat des vieux matériaux déposés dans ses Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) où ils peuvent être examinés chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une beure pm., les Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés, et ce conformément aux conditions du Cahier des Charges relatif à ces matériaux et suivant la liste y annexée dont un exemplaire peut être obtenu en Bureau de M. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) et à celui du Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire), contre paiement de 100 (cent Millièmes)

Tonte personne désirant prendre part à cette adjudication doit, au préalable, déposer à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire, à titre de cautionnement provisoire, une somme égale à 5 (Cinq pour cent) de la valeur totale des matériaux, calculée d'après les prix soumissionnés, ou se conformer aux prescriptions de l'article 9 du Cahier des charges.
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente millièmes. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à :Mr. le Directeur Général Chemins de Fer de l'Etat
Caire et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante :
"Offre pour Achat de Vieux Matériaux."
Tonte offre faite ou déposée postérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.

L'Administration se réserve le droit de choisir parmi les offres, celles qui lui conviennent, sans être tenue d'accepter l'offre la plus élevée ni n'importe quelle offre. Elle se ré. serve de même le droit de distribuer et diviser les lots et de ne donner aucune suite aux soumissions présentées, quels que soient les prix offerts.
Le Caire, le 29 Novembre 1907. 31423-2-2
